ul: For more information about SOAP array validation, see http://clawslab.nds.rub.de/wiki/index.php/Soap_Array_Attack
li: Find all code that uses SOAP messages. Create a spreadsheet of all code that handles SOAP messages. Schema validation should be performed whether or not SOAP arrays are present in messages, so include all code that handles SOAP messages in the spreadsheet.
Verify that SOAP messages are validated. Examine each piece of code that handles SOAP messages to make sure it uses schemas to validate each message before passing it to the parser.
Verify that maximum array size is specified in schemas. Examine each schema used to validate SOAP messages to make sure that all arrays have reasonable maximum sizes explicitly specified.

Find all code that uses SOAP messages. Create a spreadsheet of all code that handles SOAP messages. Schema validation should be performed whether or not SOAP arrays are present in messages, so include all code that handles SOAP messages in the spreadsheet.

Define schemas that limit the maximum size of SOAP arrays. Write a schema for each type of SOAP message that is handled by your application. Set the maximum sizes of SOAP arrays in each schema. While doing this, set the known maximums and minimums for other values in the schemas to take full advantage of schema validation.

Add code that validates SOAP array size using the schemas. Validate SOAP messages using the schema that limits the maximum size of SOAP arrays and is appropriate for the message. Validate SOAP messages before passing them to the parser.
For more information about SOAP array validation, see http://clawslab.nds.rub.de/wiki/index.php/Soap_Array_Attack
p: Verify that SOAP array sizes are validated using schemas before SOAP messages are passed to the parser.

Validate SOAP array size to prevent SOAP array abuse attacks. SOAP array abuse occurs when an attacker sends SOAP messages that say they have very large arrays in them. The parser allocates a lot of memory upon seeing such messages, so the attacker is able to exhaust the server's memory by sending a large amount of these SOAP messages rapidly. The result of SOAP array abuse is a denial of service condition.
Use this checklist item for applications that use SOAP.
To verify that SOAP array sizes are validated:

strong: Find all code that uses SOAP messages.
Verify that SOAP messages are validated.
Verify that maximum array size is specified in schemas.
Find all code that uses SOAP messages.
Define schemas that limit the maximum size of SOAP arrays.
Add code that validates SOAP array size using the schemas.

html:
Applies To

  • Web Services

What to Check For

Verify that SOAP array sizes are validated using schemas before SOAP messages are passed to the parser.

Why

Validate SOAP array size to prevent SOAP array abuse attacks. SOAP array abuse occurs when an attacker sends SOAP messages that say they have very large arrays in them. The parser allocates a lot of memory upon seeing such messages, so the attacker is able to exhaust the server's memory by sending a large amount of these SOAP messages rapidly. The result of SOAP array abuse is a denial of service condition.

When

Use this checklist item for applications that use SOAP.

How to Check

To verify that SOAP array sizes are validated:

  1. Find all code that uses SOAP messages. Create a spreadsheet of all code that handles SOAP messages. Schema validation should be performed whether or not SOAP arrays are present in messages, so include all code that handles SOAP messages in the spreadsheet.
  2. Verify that SOAP messages are validated. Examine each piece of code that handles SOAP messages to make sure it uses schemas to validate each message before passing it to the parser.
  3. Verify that maximum array size is specified in schemas. Examine each schema used to validate SOAP messages to make sure that all arrays have reasonable maximum sizes explicitly specified.

How to Fix

To validate SOAP array size:

  1. Find all code that uses SOAP messages. Create a spreadsheet of all code that handles SOAP messages. Schema validation should be performed whether or not SOAP arrays are present in messages, so include all code that handles SOAP messages in the spreadsheet.
  2. Define schemas that limit the maximum size of SOAP arrays. Write a schema for each type of SOAP message that is handled by your application. Set the maximum sizes of SOAP arrays in each schema. While doing this, set the known maximums and minimums for other values in the schemas to take full advantage of schema validation.
  3. Add code that validates SOAP array size using the schemas. Validate SOAP messages using the schema that limits the maximum size of SOAP arrays and is appropriate for the message. Validate SOAP messages before passing them to the parser.

Additional Resources

  • For more information about SOAP array validation, see http://clawslab.nds.rub.de/wiki/index.php/Soap_Array_Attack
